title: Emotional Safety
description: Learn what makes you feel understood and protected.

questions.text: What do I need from you when I'm stressed?
choices: Your presence even if we don't talk

therapeutic.rationale: Stress responses vary significantly based on attachment style and temperament. Some people need solitude to self-regulate before connecting; others need presence without demands; others need verbal processing; others need practical assistance. Offering the wrong kind of support when your partner is stressed can feel like abandonment or intrusion.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different stress needs require conscious adaptation. The space-needer may feel smothered by the presence-giver; the venter may feel dismissed by the problem-solver. State explicitly what you need when stressed: 'I need to be alone for 20 minutes, then I'll want to talk.'
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched stress responses mean you'll naturally support each other in ways that help. You understand what's needed because you need the same thing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you actually need when you're stressed? Does your partner know? What happens when they offer the wrong kind of support?

questions.text: How do I feel most emotionally connected to you?

therapeutic.rationale: Emotional connection has multiple pathways: vulnerability creates depth; physical intimacy creates bonding; shared mundane moments create companionship; comfortable silence creates peace. Understanding your partner's primary connection pathway helps you create the closeness they can feel.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different connection pathways mean you experience closeness at different moments. The vulnerability-connector may feel distant in a physically intimate but emotionally surface relationship; the silence-connector may feel pressured by constant deep talks. Balance both styles.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared connection pathways mean you'll feel bonded at the same moments. You experience 'us' the same way. Prioritize these connection moments.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When do you feel most emotionally connected to your partner? How often does this happen? What would create more of these moments?

questions.text: What do I need from you on my hardest days?
choices: Reassurance that everything will be okay

therapeutic.rationale: Our hardest days reveal our deepest needs. Some people need verbal reassurance to calm anxiety; others need practical relief from burden; others need witnessing without fixing; others need solitude and grace. How your partner responds when you're at your lowest profoundly shapes relationship security.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different crisis needs can create hurt during already hard times. The reassurance-seeker may feel abandoned by a task-focused partner; the space-needer may feel smothered by closeness. Communicate clearly: 'Today I really need...'
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched crisis needs mean you'll instinctively provide what's needed during dark times. This alignment is especially valuable when stakes are highest.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Think about your hardest recent day. What did your partner do? What did you wish they had done? How can you communicate this need clearly?

questions.text: When do I feel most understood by you?
choices: When you remember what I've told you
When you anticipate what I need
When you see beneath my surface

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling understood is a core human need. Validation says 'your feelings make sense'; remembered details say 'I've been listening'; anticipation says 'I know you'; seeing beneath says 'I know the real you.' Each creates a different flavor of being known.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different understanding triggers mean different things make you feel seen. The validation-seeker needs emotional acknowledgment; the depth-seeker needs to be seen past their defenses. Know what makes your partner feel understood.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared understanding triggers mean you'll make each other feel known in the same way. You understand what it means to be seen because you need the same thing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When was the last time you felt truly understood by your partner? What did they do? When do you feel most misunderstood?

questions.text: What makes me feel emotionally safe with you?
choices: Being able to be completely myself
How gently you handle my vulnerabilities

therapeutic.rationale: Emotional safety is the foundation of secure attachment. Authenticity-safety means no masks required; non-judgment safety means all parts accepted; availability-safety means consistently present; gentle handling means vulnerabilities protected. Without emotional safety, deep intimacy is impossible.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different safety foundations mean different things make the relationship feel secure. The consistency-seeker needs reliability; the non-judgment seeker needs acceptance. Prioritize what makes your partner feel safe.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared safety foundations mean you're building security on the same ground. You both need the same things to feel protected in the relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When do you feel most emotionally safe with your partner? When does safety waver? What would help you feel consistently protected?
